Israeli missile, artillery, and air attacks continued against Lebanon today.
Israeli forces targeted offices and homes belonging to Hezbollah, but they also attacked gas stations, highways, and ports in central and southern Lebanon.
And Hezbollah rockets reached further into Israel than in prior attacks.

Lebanese Prime Minister Fouad Siniora called on the United Nations to broker an immediate cease fire, but Israel vowed to keep up the air and sea-based attacks until Lebanon forces the disarmament of the Hezbollah militia that captured two of its soldiers earlier this week.
With us now is NPR's Ivan Watson in Beirut and Eric Westervelt in Acco, Israel.
Ivan, you've been driving around Lebanon today.
What can you report?

Well, for the first time today, Israel hit targets in central Lebanon and in northern Lebanon, far away from the Shiite Muslim communities which are pretty much the power base for the Hezbollah movement.
For instance, they hit a radar installation in the port here in Beirut.
They hit the northernmost port of Tripoli.
And these are warnings that Israel is ready to - and has been - taking apart Lebanon's infrastructure.
The country's been working for 15 years to rebuild it after its disastrous civil war.
I drove south from Beirut today and the highway linking Beirut to the southern town of Sidon has basically been cut.
Every bridge along the way has been demolished by Israeli air strikes.
And there was intensive bombardment of the southern neighborhoods of Beirut, where Hezbollah is based.
And in the southern border areas, as well, intense fighting.
